{{Infobox musical artist | name = Golden "Big" Wheeler | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Golden Wheeler | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1929|12|15|mf=y}}
[[Baconton, Georgia]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1998|7|20|1929|12|15|mf=y}}
[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[harmonica]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[List of harmonicists|harmonicist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Late 1940s–1998 | label = [[Delmark Records|Delmark]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Golden "Big" Wheeler''' (December 15, 1929 – July 20, 1998){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1998.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1998 - 1999 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[List of harmonicists|harmonicist]] and [[songwriter]]. He released two albums in his lifetime, and is best known for his recordings of the songs "Damn Good Mojo" and "Bone Orchard". He worked with the Ice Cream Men and [[Jimmy Johnson (blues guitarist)|Jimmy Johnson]], and was the brother of fellow blues musician, James Wheeler. ==Biography== He was born '''Golden Wheeler''' in [[Baconton, Georgia|Baconton]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. Wheeler left Georgia in 1941 and settled in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], in July 1954, where he befriended [[Little Walter]]. His enthusiasm for playing the [[harmonica]] began when he was working as a [[Taxicabs of the United States|taxicab]] driver. One of his regular customers was the harmonica player [[Buster Brown (musician)|Buster Brown]], who later went on to have a [[hit record]] with "[[Fannie Mae (song)|Fannie Mae]]" in 1960. Wheeler [[frontman|fronted]] his own [[musical ensemble|band]] by 1956, although he was a part-time musician, having to work for years as an [[auto mechanic]] to help raise his family. In 1993, Wheeler released his first [[album]], ''Bone Orchard'', where he was backed by a local outfit, the Ice Cream Men. Released by [[Delmark Records]] (Delmark 661), it recreated a 1950s feel with a double [[guitar]] and [[drum]] backing, with no [[bass guitar]]. The Ice Cream Men comprised Johnny Burgin and Dave Waldman (guitars), plus Steve Cushing (drums). The album was [[record producer|produced]] by Robert G. Koester.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bone-orchard-mw0000103649/credits |title=Bone Orchard - Big Wheeler | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} His next issue was ''Jump In'' (1997), where his backing included a fuller sound incorporating his brother, James Wheeler, on guitar.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p33680/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Big Wheeler |author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=May 25, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.delmark.com/delmark.709.htm |title=Golden "Big" Wheeler: ''Jump In'' |author= |publisher=Delmark.com|accessdate=May 25, 2010}} As well as the Wheeler brothers, other musicians utilised on the album were Baldhead Pete (drums), Allen Batts (piano) and [[Bob Stroger]] (bass), with Koester again producing the overall set.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/jump-in-mw0000597358/credits |title=Jump In - Big Wheeler | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Golden "Big" Wheeler died of [[heart failure]] in Chicago in July 1998, at the age of 68. ==Discography== ===Albums=== *''Bone Orchard'' (1993) - [[Delmark Records|Delmark]] *''Jump In'' (1997) - Delmark{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-wheeler-mn0000064444/discography |title=Big Wheeler | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1929-12-15 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==See also== *[[List of harmonicists]] *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME =Wheeler, Golden | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[Chicago blues]] singer | DATE OF BIRTH = December 15, 1929 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Baconton, Georgia]] | DATE OF DEATH = July 20, 1998 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wheeler, Golden}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:1998 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Deaths from heart failure]] [[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]]
